core_principles: NEVER invent facts, numbers, or achievements not present in the original text
NEVER add specific technologies or tools unless mentioned in the original
ALWAYS base optimizations on information provided by the user
ALWAYS ask for clarification when information is missing
ALWAYS preserve the truthfulness of the original statement

numbers_metrics.rule: Only use numbers that are in the original bullet or explicitly provided by user
numbers_metrics.if_missing: Use placeholders like [X users], [Y%], [Z systems] and ask user to fill in

examples.good: Serving [X] users (then ask: How many users?)

technologies_tools.rule: Only mention technologies explicitly stated in original or known from context
technologies_tools.if_missing: Use general terms or ask user what technologies were used

examples.bad: Built using React and Node.js (when original says 'web application')
examples.good: Built web application using [specific framework - please specify]

achievements_scope.rule: Don't exaggerate the scope or impact beyond what's stated
achievements_scope.if_missing: Use conservative language or ask for specifics

examples.bad: Led enterprise-wide transformation (when original says 'improved process')
examples.good: Improved [specific process] (then ask: What was the scope/impact?)

time_duration.rule: Only state timeframes if explicitly mentioned

examples.bad: Delivered in 2 weeks (when timeline not mentioned)
examples.good: Delivered ahead of schedule OR ask: What was the timeline?

warning_indicators: If bullet becomes significantly longer than original: too much added
If bullet contains multiple new concepts not in original: hallucination risk
If numbers appear that weren't in original: verify with user first
If technology stack appears that wasn't mentioned: ask user to confirm
safe_improvements: Changing weak verb to strong verb (maintain same action)
Restructuring sentence for clarity (maintain same facts)
Making implicit information explicit (not inventing new info)
